intro: Humboltia archidonae, commonly known as the Archidonae's humboldtia, is a rare flowering plant native to the coastal regions of central Chile. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and showy flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy soils along the Pacific coast, thriving in the temperate climate of its native habitat. Its flowers are usually pink or red, with five petals and a distinctive corolla shape. Humboltia archidonae is known for its ecological importance in supporting local pollinators and its unique adaptations to coastal environments.
